Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Grantees and Future Research Directions in Service, Manufacturing, and Operations Research (NSF-SMOR) Southern Methodist University, Dallas, TX; October 9-11, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this workshop is to bring together SMOR (Service, Manufacturing, and Operations Research) grantees and researchers with the purpose of identifying promising future research directions with significant impact on theory and practice. The workshop will also serve as a grantees conference in which the attending grantees will have the opportunity to display and present posters on their current grants. It is also our expectation that the interactions between participants will pave the way for collaborative research agendas among them in the future.

This workshop is motivated by the new SMOR program structure, which includes the ingredients -- applications, data, and methodologies -- and the need to identify future directions via collaboration of researchers and practitioners from each of the three ingredients. The workshop will facilitate discussions on three interconnected topics including societal impact, analytics and curricular updates, and interface with human behavior and organization behavior/change. Following state-of-the-art keynotes on methods (optimization and data science) and applications (healthcare systems, supply chains and service systems, energy systems and sustainability, and manufacturing systems/cybermanufacturing) to set the stage, multiple breakout sessions with 10-12 participants will be formed to discuss future directions of research that connect methodologies and applications through data availability (with both increased size and variety available today) for realistic applications with societal impact. A second topic of discussion will focus on the efficiency and effectiveness at the interface between typical SMOR program research areas, which by and large focus on the design of systems and processes for low-touch products and services, and the high-touch systems in which the customer has a direct relationship with the provider (i.e., incorporating both the human and organizational behavior aspects). Finally, in the wake of explosion in data availability and many recent practices it facilitates, the workshop will provide the opportunity to identify a roadmap for curricular changes in teaching OR/MS theory and practice to next generation of engineers and business leaders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop took place on SMU campus. It included three keynote speakers and five breakout sessions with six parallel meetings where three topics were discussed. The workshop also included a poster session (31 posters).  All organizational details and activities can be found at https://people.smu.edu/nsfworkshop/

Topic 1: Societal Impact

Discussion on societal impact has been focused on future research directions that develop and connect methodologies and applications through data availability in realistic applications. Breakout session participants have discussed how to measure societal impact and proposed the critical areas (problem types vs. application areas) where there are opportunities for far-reaching impact via inter-disciplinary collaboration. Recognizing that topics covered by the OE Program are enablers of new products, processes, and services, but not owners, the focus has been on how to communicate a better understanding of what we (are able to) do. An accompanying topic has been how we develop communities of OE researchers and users/creators of enabling technologies and what mechanisms that NSF can support to foster such activities.

The critical areas have been identified as environment, healthcare, traditional vs. emerging supply chain structures (sharing economy, online consolidation of retailers vs. mass retailers), illicit supply chains/operations.  One particular theme has been analysis of social impact for all stakeholders, including the current and next generation of stakeholders. The discussion has emphasized the need to define specific metrics for societal impact for the critical areas and stakeholder. Metrics would be useful for creating an increased understanding of the topics covered by the OE program and help identify strategies for forming collaborations with communities of researchers (educators, psychologists, economists, medical professionals and doctors, computer scientists, engineers from various disciplines, public policy experts, etc.)

Topic 2: Interface of ORMS/Analytics with Human & Organizational Behavior and Change

High-touch systems are systems that humans interact with directly to obtain goods and services specifically serving their needs. In healthcare, an example would be the scheduling of surgeons and operating rooms that takes into account surgeons? and patients? preferences. Such decisions must be made repeatedly. The sharing economy provides another example that pertains to inventory sharing. Other examples include insurance services, airlines, education, human trafficking, refugee settlement, disaster evacuation, consulting, financial services, among others. 

The increase in data and technology has made it possible to meet more human needs, but that also means that the decision problems become more complex. With this in mind, the discussions in breakout sessions first focused on how to measure the quality of a high-touch system as this may differ from a central decision maker?s perspective common in low-touch systems. This then is followed by identifying the need to incorporate alternative quality measures as objectives in analytical modeling of these systems. Next, with the recognition of high interaction with customers in delivering products and services to cater their needs directly, the attendees discussed how institutions should organize themselves to achieve high quality interactions and identified the need for special care in designing their products and processes. Also, while it is easier to test new products and/or efficiency of processes in low touch (e.g., conventional manufacturing to inventory) systems, it was determined that how these changes can be tested in a laboratory setting. These activities will require close collaboration between OR/MS and human-/organization-factors researchers and can be facilitated effectively by NSF. The attendees discussed alternative means of achieving this as recommendations such as programs that directly seek industry-academia collaborations for that purpose. Finally, the participants discussed potential roadblocks and difficulties that can be faced in implementation and how these can be avoided/reduced proactively in the research and design phase.

Topic 3: Teaching ORMS/Analytics Theory and Practice

Many engineering schools have analytics minors at undergraduate level and MS programs while some schools are developing data science programs at the PhD level. Business schools offer business analytics degrees at the masters level. OR/MS community at these universities has been at the forefront of such initiatives. Recognizing the steps taken toward curriculum development, the attendees have discussed the needs and challenges of curricula going forward.

Discussion has focused on interactions among descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive analytics and their integration as opposed to treating them as separate disciplines. OR/MS community with its systems focus is the best fitting discipline to undertake this objective. In doing so, the IE/OR departments across the nation should prepare their students by incorporating concepts and tools that are relevant for today?s digitally-focused world. In this regard, the ideas discussed in this workshop broadly targeted toward undergraduate students through minor programs that cut across multiple disciplines, and concentrated tracks at the Master?s level. Alternative approaches discussed have included model-based learning and tool-based learning; emphasizing the need to have core method courses with some domain-specific elective courses.  It has been advocated that curricula must also include professional leadership program to enhance soft skills and active industry engagement.
